metadata.author: Garrett Dash Nelson
metadata.title: Narrating maps and images with panel-truck
metadata.subtitle: An interactive tool from the Leventhal Map & Education Center

caption.title: A caption may have a title
caption.text: And descriptive text telling the reader what we're looking at. This image is loaded from a IIIF Manifest, by passing the Manifest URL together with a sequence, canvas, and image indices.

caption.title: Taking a tour
caption.text: We can tour around the image by changing the extent that we want featured in the view.
A caption doesn't need a title; only the text is required. **Markdown** _is also_ supported, and we can [insert links](https://leventhalmap.org)

caption.title: Jumping to a new image in the same Manifest
caption.text: Now we've jumped over to another image from the same Manifest.
And now we're panning around that image. You can pan around as much as you like, at any zoom level.

caption.title: IIIF Single Image
caption.text: If we don't want to load from a Manifest, we can pass an Image endpoint directly, instead

caption.title: But not everybody uses IIIF!
caption.text: That's true ... which is why we can also pass in a static image
Image extents are in positive pixel coordinates from the lower left corner. We can also override the moreInfo link for a specific slide.
We can also use real world maps; this one is from OSM
And now we're zooming the map to a new extent
If we have a custom web map, we can pass it in using either a TileJSON ...
... or as a standard XYZ schema. Map scenes use EPSG:3857 (Web Mercator) coordinates for their extents.
If you don't provide an extent for a geographic map, it will zoom to the entire world.
